column30: Differences in regulation,Lawful basis for processing
column31: We have a law for data use (storage, protection, etc), but it is not clear to everyone. There are many differences between countries and sometimes it is difficult to arrive in a datashare agreement. One of the problems is to define who is responsible to provide it and which rules are going to be applied. We have an office for research support in our institution, but, because of those problems, it always take too long.
column32: Data use agreements,Equitable access and benefits
column33: Professionals that work in research support offices should have more knowledge about datashare agreements. Researchers should be educated to those rules and participate in the process of changing them.

column33:
Everything is done in an ad hoc basis, by non-lawyers, and based on personal relations. Templates for data-sharing agreements would help, but there are cultural issues in play that are quite intractable ('my data' here enphasizes the possessive pronoum).

The formation of consortioums with clearly stated expectations for data sharing would also help.

Finally, specific training for data scientists and other researchers
column34: A clear set of data sharing licences, akin to creative commons licences, but designed with scientific data in mind,  that clearly delineate what each party is entitled to
